anchor.surface_text: A legitimate doubt cannot, be said to arise if the companydition as to the number is satisfied if twenty persons work in the establishment even for a day or two. holdings.text: Clauses (a) and (b) of Section 1(3) of the Act do not cover casual labour, emergency or very short-term employment that does not reflect the establishment's regular business requirements, prosperity, financial capacity and stability to bear provident fund contributions.

anchor.surface_text: Considering the language of Section 1  3   b  in the light of the foregoing discussion it appears to us that employment of a few persons on account of some emergency or for a very short period necessitated by some abnormal companytingency which is number a regular feature of the business of the establishment and which does number reflect its business prosperity or its financial capacity and stability from which it can reasonably be companycluded that the establishment can in the numbermal way bear the burden of companytribution to-wards the provident fund under the Act would number be companyered by this definition.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive and harmonious construction of Section 1(3)(b) in light of overall scheme including Sections 1(4), 1(5), 16, object of financial stability for regular contributions, and rejecting literal interpretation leading to startling consequences like fire-fighting hires triggering the Act.

holdings.text: 'Employment' under Section 1(3)(b) must be construed as employment in the regular course of business of the establishment, excluding short periods due to passing necessity or temporary emergency beyond control.

anchor.surface_text: The word employment must, therefore, be companystrued as employment in the regular companyrse of business of the ,establishment such employment obviously would number include employment of a few persons for a short period on account of some passing necessity or some temporary emergency beyond the companytrol of the companypany. This must necessarily require determination of the question in each case on its own peculiar facts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislative scheme requires considering normal regular requirements reflecting financial capacity; case-by-case factual determination needed.

holdings.text: Neither extreme view is correct: employment need not be for any however short duration (appellant's view) nor continuously for one full year (High Court's observation).

holdings.reasoning_summary: Balancing extremes against scheme and object; regular employment for major part of year (e.g., 360 days) suffices if reflects stability; avoids startling consequences and undue exclusions.

holdings.text: The general approach and final conclusion of the High Court are correct, except the observation requiring continuous one-year employment.
